text: The soldiers tear out bandages from a half-burned Medic K and stuff them against the bleeding.  3.4.13 2. A MORTAR ROUND lands nearby, showering them all with dirt debris. We black out. --Looking up at two men carrying our body... --Heading down a ladder --We’re loaded onto a stretcher and shoved into an ambula As the doors close, we briefly catch a glimpse of one of medics shaking his head at the captain. The MONTAGE ENDS as we’re given a shot of morphine.
In contrast, these mountains lush and green, thick with o growth timber and flowering shrubs. Titles: EIGHTEEN YEARS EARLIER... Lynchburg, Virginia

Norman Rockwell come to life. Small wooden houses on the rolling hills of the Virginia Piedmont, more country than city. Two boys are rolling a coaster wagon through their yard. DESMOND, the younger, 8 years old, pushes; his brot MARK, 10, holds the wagon tongue and steers. The wagon contains a collection of rusty junk metal. The wagon is heavy and the boys small, but they’re tough and determined. They’re like Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn. (NOTE: The real Desmond Doss, throughout his life, spoke with the distinct accent of the Virginia’s Blue Ridge Mountains, a lilting and beautiful usage that persists in some places to this day. We make no attempt to render tha accent in these pages, but the presence of it in his spee brought even more distinction and majesty to his real character.) Sitting on the front porch of their house is their father TOM DOSS. Tom is a big man, sullen man, broken in his sou
What you boys doin’?
We're making money!  3.4.13 3.
At the filling station they’re buying scrap metal! Any old junk we haul in, they’1l give us cash money!
We got lotsa junk in the back yard!

You know why they want it? The boys hadn’t even considered that. TOM (cont'd) They sell it overseas. The Japs and Germans make weapons out of it. Tom rubs his neck, where there’s a nasty scar from World I. More than his neck is scarred--but his boys are innocents.
Can we take it?
Do what you want. But when those plow tips and lug nuts go whistling by your ears, you'll say your daddy was right. The boys head around behind the house, Mark whispering to Desmond--
Come on--he ain’t never right about nothin’.
The boys are digging through a trove of cast off parts fr old farm equipment. Then young Desmond spots a coin, and lifts it, spitting on it to clean it. It’s a dime.
Look! I found a dime!
(jealous) That’s mine.
It ain’t yours.  3.4.13 4.

I lost it, give it here. He reaches for it--but Desmond snatches his hand away...a suddenly the fight’s on. They’re real scrappers, rolling around on the ground, punching, kicking, scratching. This isn’t their first fight with each other. Mark finally pins Desmond.
Say Uncle! SAY UNCLE!

No! Desmond may be younger and smaller but he’s every bit his brother’s equal in grit and determination. He elbows Mark the face and shoves him off. In a blind fury, Desmond gra a good size rock and lifts it over his head with both han no thought for what he’s about to do but... ...A LARGE HAND reaches into frame, grabs Desmond by his scrawny wrist, and yanks him off his brother.

head_text.subj: WHAT THE HELL YOU THINK YOU'RE

text: Tom stands over them, holding a kicking, struggling Desmo up in the air like a bug. Tom folds Desmond over one arm begins walloping him on the ass with the other - big, har strokes which echo like gunshots.

Jack! That’s enough of that! BERTHA, Desmond’s mother, stands behind them. She’s a sma woman but fierce in her own way. Tom looks at her with defiance but he lets Desmond go, and the boy falls to the ground like a sack of potatoes.
He was beating on his brother.
Beating on him doesn’t teach him any different. Tom waves his hand in half-hearted acquiescence.
You're gonna spoil him is all.  3.4.13 5.

head_text.subj: AN ILLUSTRATION OF THE TEN COMMANDMENTS

text: The Doss house doesn’t contain much art work, and this wouldn't qualify as art to most people; it’s more like a cartoon, illustrating each of the ten commandments. Desmond’s eyes drift over the illustrations; but then the settle on one that has particular relevance: THOU SHALT N KILL, depicted by Cain holding a bloody club, standing ov the prostrate body of his dead brother, Abel. There is a look of utter horror on Cain’s face.
Murder is the worst sin of all. We’re all brothers and to take another man’s life is the most grievous thing there is in the Lord's sight. Nothing hurts His heart so much.

Bertha kneels on an old worn sofa with Desmond and Mark standing beside her. They are both looking at a framed illustration of the Ten Commandments hanging on the wall. Bertha turns and pulls Desmond down into her lap but his rimmed eyes never leave the print.
Why did Cain kill Abel?

Oh, he was mad, I suppose. Or he wanted what his brother had. It doesn’t matter why - it’s always wrong. Mark is silent, but Desmond is transfixed, unable to stop staring at that gruesome primal scene of the first murder

The sun’s going down, and Tom Doss is sitting on his fron porch, bored and sullen. He reaches to the firewood box beside his chair, and from behind it he draws a Masan jar half full of clear liquid--moonshine. He takes a sip. From inside he hears Mark's voice.  3.4.13 6.
Daddy?! Can we get down now?! He tucks the jar away quickly and wipes his mouth.
Ask your Mama, she’s the one didn’t want to whip you!
Mark hops off the chair, leaving Desmond still in the position where their mother left them. Mark heads into th kitchen...
Mrs. Doss is cooking dinner as Mark comes in, wearing an expression of exaggerated pennance.
Mama, can we stop staring at the Commendments?
Commandments. Are you sorry?
Yes’m.
Tell Desmond.
(without moving)

Okay, you can go. Bertha stands for a moment wondering why she hasn’t heard response from Desmond. BERTHA (cont'd) Desmond? (beat) Des? She moves into the living room, and finds her youngest so now standing, staring straight at the picture.  3.4.13 7. BERTHA (cont'd) Desmond?... FROM THE POV OF THE PICTURE, we see Desmond’s stare, his entire soul fixed on it. He’s staring at CAIN, A LOOK OF HORROR ON HIS FACE at wha he’s done. There are tears in Desmond’s eyes. And BERTHA realizes with a certainty what she has always suspected: Desmond feels things in a unique way.

Title: Fourteen years later. Lynchburg has always been a railroad town; tracks cut thr the gorges and span ridges. Twenty-five year old Desmond now walks alongside the trac He’s grown into a thin but wiry man with a pleasant but crooked smile. His senses are keen; he hears the chirp of a bird and his blue eyes catch sight of a bright red Cardinal high in a hickory tree. He’s a true country boy, at one with nature

Desmond waits his turn. Fascinated by all things medical, can’t help but poke around in the shelves and cabinets. T door behind him opens and Desmond whirls around, embarras to be caught snooping. He’s even more embarrassed as sees his attendant is an attractive nurse, DOROTHY SHUTTE, early 20's.
Anything in particular you're looking for?
No, ma‘am. I’m just kind of interested in medicine. He stammers slightly, with nerves. DESMOND (cont'd) I used dream about being a doctor. But I didn’t get much school.  3.4.13 8.
You ever given blood before, Mr...? Dorothy consults her clipboard.
Doss. But my friends call me Desmond. No, ma’am, this would be my first time. When they made the announcement in church about a big car wreck and folks needing blood SO...

Just lie back here. Desmond has no idea what to do--it’s his first time on a hospital table. Dorothy is patient and kind, sensing his country boy innocence. Desmond watches EVERY DETAIL as she rolls back his sleeve dips a cotton ball in alcohol and wipes the crook of his elbow with it. For Desmond, it’s almost romantic. Then she wraps and elastic tourniquet around his bicep, a slips an IV needle into his vein. She notices that it makes him a little pale and queasy; s smiles gently. DOROTHY (cont'd) You might be a little dizzy when we're done. Is somebody picking you up?
No, ma’am, I walked from home. Dorothy watches the RED BLOOD, FILLING THE COLLECTION BAG
Where do you live?
Fort Hill.
That’s a ways.
Just five or six miles. But I cut through the woods. It’s seven that way!  3.4.13 9. He laughs. She laughs too.
You must like the woods.

I always feel lost everywhere else. But there I can find my way. Dorothy takes this in; Desmond seems so simple, so boyish even backward. But something about him is deep, and poeti And unique. It brings out the sweetness in her.
Well I have to tell you, Mr. Doss. For somebody to walk ten or twelve miles, to give blood to strangers... I wish everybody was like you.
Thank you, ‘mam.
You don’t have to call me ‘mam. It’s Dorothy.
Dorothy. Yes ‘Mam! She smiles; is he flirting? She gets up.
You’1l be done in a minute. We have cookies and Kool-Aid. Help restore your blood sugar.
Giving blood’s got all sorts of benefits.

Desmond enters, more exhilarated than tired despite his l walk and the loss of blood but his face falls when he see his father sitting, slumped, in his rocker. He’s been drinking and has fallen asleep clutching a pint of whiske Not an unfamiliar sight. Desmond considers him a moment a then gently tries to extract the bottle from his grasp. T eyes blink open.
Excuse you?!  3.4.13 10.
You need some help getting upstairs, sir? Tom pushes Desmond away and rises unsteadily, still clutc his bottle.
Not from you. Bertha appears in the kitchen doorway, nervously holding dish towel.
You hungry, Tom? Tom just glares at her and makes his way slowly toward th stairs.

Desmond and Bertha sit, eating a cold supper. She hasn’t touched hers. Desmond silently reaches over and holds her hand. Desmond’s brother Mark strolls in the back door. He kisse his mother and nudges Desmond's shoulder, sitting at the table. BERTHA (cont'd) I was wondering if you were gonna make it to dinner.
I went by to see the recruiters. Bertha involuntarily glances upstairs, afraid her husband might hear.
Your daddy won’t like that.

Daddy ain’t payin’ my bills. If there’s a war they’1l need men--and the paper mill doesn’t need any. Mark digs in and starts eating. Bertha is distressed at t news; Desmond changes the subject.  3.4.13 11.
Met somebody today, a nurse over at the hospital. Her name’s Dorothy Shutte and I’m gonna marry her. Bertha blinks in surprise.
Goodness. Does she know?
I haven't gotten around to telling her just yet. Mark grins, and punches Desmond again. Desmond smiles...t punches him back. The brothers laugh.
Dorothy is working at her station when she looks up to se Desmond standing there.
Desmond?
Hi, Dorothy. How'd the blood drive go.
The church announcements worked really well! We got more than enough.
Well, that’s good. Cause I need my blood back.
You what?
My blood. I need it back.
But...we can’t just give it back to you.  3.4.13 12.
Well you got to, because ever since you stuck me with that needle, my heart’s been beating fast, and every time I think about you, it beats faster still.
Is that a pick up line?
Is it working?

A movie plays on the screen as Desmond and Dorothy make t way to their seats, obviously late. As they sit, Dorothy starts to watch the movie. Desmond can’t help but admire beauty. He sits awkwardly, trying to find a way to connec with her. He tries to stretch and put his arm around her, but when looks at him he fumbles a bit to try and recover. She sim smiles and takes a sip of her cola. Desmond sits in silen again and then tries to have his hand brush up against he As he does this, Dorothy preempts him and holds his hand. For that moment, neither of them are watching the movie. Instead they are both looking into each other's eyes. Desmond slowly leans in and they share their first kiss. Our music rises into a MONTAGE of Desmond and Dorothy’s growing love:
Desmond and Dorothy hike through the park and look out ac the landscape.

Desmond gets onto an old rope swing just after Dorothy ge off. As Dorothy begins swinging him; she sees Desmond not a pretty girl walking past. Frustrated, she tugs the rope sideways and Desmond swings into the tree... Dorothy stalks away after Desmond’s crash, but he gets up catches her and explains something we don't hear but understand. Dorothy softens and smiles...  3.4.13 13.
Desmond and Dorothy chat furiously across the table, bare having time to take bites of their food. Something Desmon says cracks Dorothy up.
Dorothy opens her locker to find an orange and a note fro Desmond. Her look of confusion on finding the orange turn to a smile as she reads the note.
The leaves are falling from the tress as Desmond and Doro walk through the woods, talking. The MONTAGE ENDS as Doro puts her head on Desmond’s shoulder.
A glorious late Fall day with just a bit of color lingeri on the trees. Desmond and Dorothy are walking with other tourists, gazing up at Natural Bridge.
They say George Washington threw a silver dollar over it.
Seems like a waste of a dollar to me.

I doubt anybody's throwing money at it these days! (more seriously) The plant foreman told me the other day that I’m doing such a good job, they might raise me up a notch. Salary too. Hope that doesn’t sound too much like bragging.
So, you’re gonna be a man of means, Mr. Doss?

I’m a man who means to be one. She looks at him, realizing he’s planning a future, one that’s built around her. Slowly, happily, they kiss.  3.4.13 14. EXT./INT. COUNTRY ROAD / DESMOND’S CAR - AFTERNOON Desmond and Dorothy drive back to town - they are both ag with their love. As they pull into town, Dorothy notices several cars pull over to the side of the road and people crowded around th doorway to a coffee shop.
Desmond... She doesn’t even need to finish her thought; Desmond has already started to pull over.
Desmond and Dorothy join the crowd that has gathered at t coffee shop, just within earshot of the door. Everyone lo nervously at the radio inside, listening to President Roosevelt.
...the United States of America was suddenly and deliberately attacked by the naval and air forces of the Empire of Japan! Roosevelt's speech continues as we CUT TO:

A long line of men are already waiting their turn to sign We move through the line of faces, some older, some young everyone wanting to do their part as Roosevelt’s speech p over. Men continue to join the line, some obviously have come from work, both in suits and in uniforms.

...-As commander in chief of the Army and Navy, I have directed that all measures be taken for our defense. But always will our whole nation remember the character of the onslaught against us. No matter how long it may take us to overcome this premeditated invasion, the American people in their righteous might will win through to absolute victory. CEMETERY SEQUENCE...  3.4.13 15. We see various CLOSE SHOTS OF GRAVESTONES, from a low ang jabbing up into the sky... We PAN ACROSS them, a whole forest of stones, like a whol army of soldiers who have become stone slabs as they died battle. We are...

The cemetery is in the very heart of the town, on a hill surrounded by brick walls. And Desmond Doss’s father, Tom is standing among the grave stones. It’s an old and seemingly haunted place where few people visit; for awhile he seems all alone, until he hears--
Daddy?... Tom turns around and stands silently as Desmond approache DESMOND (cont'd) Mama told me you wanted to see me. Here?

Here. Yeah. He walks away slowly and Desmond follows, completely in t dark about why his father has made such a strange demand. They reach a section of low stones, their perfect lines n twisted by tree roots and time, their once-smooth surface pitted by weather and pocked by moss.
Confederates.

Soldiers. Boys from World War One are over yonder. Even got some from the Revolutionary War on the hill someplace. Desmond's eyes lift toward his father, starting to unders why his father wanted him to come here. TOM (cont'd) Look at ‘em. All of ‘em soldiers. All of ‘em boys. And all of ‘em dead.  3.4.13 16. Tom sounds angry, and bitter, as he always has to Desmond but for the first time in his life Desmond hears an emoti in his father’s voice too. TOM (cont'd) I don’t want my boys here. I don’t want you here. Desmond’s eyes meet Tom’s; there are tears in Tom’s eyes. Desmond is transfixed.
Mark’s already joined up. The Marine Corps--

(trying to regain control) I know that... Tom coughs--a wet, smoker’s cough that makes Desmond want go try to comfort him, but from force of habit he holds b Tom sags, supporting himself against one of the graveston TOM (cont'd) I don’t want you in this graveyard. I don’t want you to go to war.
Daddy...

I know they’re drafting! But I still got a friend or two! One of ‘em works at the Foundry, making steel they use for ships and tanks and such as that. They call it an “essential defense industry,” and they’1l leave you alone if you work there. I can get you on. They--
Daddy. I already signed up.
What?
I talked to them at the draft board today. Desmond watches his father. He approaches him tenderly.  3.4.13 17. DESMOND (cont'd) Daddy, I--
Get your hand off me! YOU ARE STUPID! DAMN YOU!! First time in your life I give you the chance to do something smart, and you do this?!
Everybody else is--

You ain’t everybody else! Everybody else jumps in and does things quick, without thinking! And soldiers who live, they live because they can do that! You can’t! You gotta sit and think and pray about everything! Desmond stands there trying to find words, trying to find solid ground in this sudden sea of emotion. TOM (cont'd) You're doing it right now. (beat) You're a terrible son. I hope they kill ya. Tom staggers off, through the old headstones of the dead soldiers.

Bertha sits crying, alone in the living room. She’s holdi something in her hands: pictures of her sons, Mark and Desmond. Her tears fall on the glass of the frames. Through the front windows she sees the back of her husban he sits on the porch, sullen, drinking. She’s all alone.

The platform is crowded with young men - recruits - being sent off by family, friends, wives, and girlfriends. Desm and Dorothy are embracing. The waiting train sounds a shr whistle - time to get aboard.  3.4.13 18.
Are you sure...this is right? It’s what you’re really meant to do?
I’m just sure I can’t sit back and do nothing.
(trying not to cry) I know.
I am sure of something, though. I don’t really have the right to be asking you, and we haven’t known each other for very long, but I can’t imagine...
Yes.
You don’t know what I’m about to ask.

Yes, I do, and the answer is, yes. I do. They kiss. Dot pulls out a small pocket NEW TESTAMENT and hands it to Desmond. DOROTHY (cont'd) You keep this with you, all the time. Promise? Desmond nods and tucks it away carefully in his shirt poc The train blows a second, final whistle and starts to slo pull out.
When?
Soon as you get leave. Let me know. Desmond jumps onto the steps of the moving train. Dorothy walks alongside, reluctant to let go of his hand.
I love you!  3.4.13 19. The train is picking up speed. Dorothy has to let go.
Desmond sits with the other young men as the train moves slowly along the rails, past the hickory and oak trees th line the tracks. They rumble over a trestle, and Desmond realizes--
(to himself) We're going by my house! A thought strikes him; he looks around at the other young guys. DESMOND (cont'd) Anybody got some paper? Anything? Anything I could write on?
I got some writing paper.

Can you loan me a sheet, I’1l pay you back! The guy gives Desmond a cheap tablet; Desmond tears off a sheet and hurriedly pulls a pencil from his pocket to wri He’s rushing--but he takes the time to write, with feelin
“DADDY...I LOVE YOU. DESMOND”
Desmond opens the door, braces his foot on the step, and reaches down to the track bed; he deftly scoops up a larg rock, and wraps the paper around it.
The train chugs slowly over the trestle; Desmond, leaning from the train car, sees his house far below. With all hi might he throws the rock. It arcs through the air...

But the train’s WHISTLE drowns out his scream...  3.4.13 20. And the rock falls to the ground, just shy of the Doss’s yard. Unseen. Desmond sees that his message didn’t make it. He sees his father sitting sullenly on the front porch, a disappearin speck in the distance.
Desmond sits in an old green Army bus jammed with young recruits, full of nervous energy and excitement. He runs fingers over the pocket New Testament Dot gave him as the enters the gates of...

location: FT. JACKSON, S. CAROLINA, U.S. ARMY HQ 307TH INFANTR

text: A sign boasts: Proud Home of the “Statue of Liberty” Brigade! Groups of sweaty soldiers run past, harassed by their perpetually dissatisfied Drill Instructors. Desmond’s bus stops and the recruits file out. Immediately, SGT. HOWELL no-nonsense NCO from Alabama, is screaming at them.
WHAT’RE YOU DOIN’ STANDIN’ THERE?!

Desmond and the new recruits are pushed and herded quickl through a series of stations where they are thrown unifor duffel bags, boots, kits. Throughout, Howell is continuou yelling and berating the recruits. Desmond is both excited and anxious - he’s never been awa from home before and never been around such a group.

Desmond enters his new housing. The barracks are stifling even with all the windows open. There are a dozen other RECRUITS here, all men older then you might expect - the average age is close to 32. Most of Desmond's platoon hav been here for days already and the men glance at their ne comrade with casual interest.  3.4.13 21. SMITTY, a burly dockworker, is playing a knife game - “stretch” - against “GREASE” NOLAN, another Brooklyn nati and auto mechanic. Smitty balances the knife with an ease suggesting intimate familiarity and expertly throws it in the floor, 30 inches from Grease’s right foot. Grease groans. He has to spread his legs even wider to try and reach the knife. Try as he might, Grease just can’t make it.

Shoot! You’re up, Kirzinski. Grease moves over and another man, KIRZINKSI, takes his place. Grease sidles up to Desmond and extends his hand. GREASE (cont'd) Grease Nolan outta Red Hook. Where you from?
Virginia. Desmond, Desmond Doss.
Hillbilly, huh? That’s Smitty there, whipping Kirzinski’s ass.

Like you were doing better. Smitty says nothing but as the Alpha Dog in the bunch he gives Desmond a very thorough if silent scrutiny. “TEACH” EPSTEIN, a High School math teacher from Hartford glances up from his pulp magazine and smiles.
Zeke Epstein. Most guys call me “Teach.” Grease steers Doss towards the back of the barracks.

Think we got an empty bunk back here. Grease pauses near the corner where a group of men are intently playing craps. MILT “HOLLYWOOD” ZANE, a professional gambler from Los Angeles, rolls the dice - sevens - and scoops up the pot.  3.4.13 22.
Seven is heaven! Come to daddy! (glancing at Desmond) Fresh blood! Care to sit in?
No, thanks.
Not as dumb as you look! That’s Hollywood Zane. Scott Drucker there’s a genuine Mohawk from upstate New York. Say something in Indian, Chief. “CHIEF” Drucker looks at Grease with undisguised contempt

Ugh. Mazilli, a big burly redhead with a thick Boston accent reaches over and shakes Desmond’s hand. BRUNO “B” MAZILLI Bruno Mazilli. Beantown. Guys call me B. Grease gestures to the far corner where TEX ROYAL, a ranc hand from Abilene, is showing off rope tricks to VITO RINNELLI.
That’s Tex over there and Vito Rinnelli. Here, I don’t think anybody's using this bunk. The barracks’ door opens and Sgt. Howell bursts in. Smitt leaps to attention and yells out.
‘TENTION! Everyone immediately drops what they are doing and stands

head_text.subj: COMPANY B ON THE ROPES COURSE. FIVE

text: The men are marched over to a climbing station where they each handed a rope.  3.4.13 23.

(yelling) I am going to teach you how to tie a bowline knot so you can get your sorry asses down from a height so I can kick it! Pay attention! Make a loop. Run the tail end thru the loop and around the rope. Run it back through the loop and pull it tight! Alright, let’s go!! The men struggle to follow Howell’s instructions. Tex, of course, is perfect but many are flummoxed. Howell walks d the line, testing each knot. He tugs Grease’s clumsy creation and it comes apart in his big meaty hands. SGT. HOWELL (cont'd) Congratulations, Dumb-ass, you just fell fifty feet and broke your neck! Howell grabs Zane’s rope and the knot actually slips, clo the loop. SGT. HOWELL (cont'd) Brilliant, Private Zane--you just strangled yourself, numb nuts! Howell gets to Desmond who, to his embarrassment, has inadvertently doubled his rope and actually tied not one, two loops. SGT. HOWELL (cont'd) What’ve you got here, Doss, one for each titty? You’re tying a bowline, boy, not building a bra! Desmond blushes and laughs at himself. There’s a good feeling in the group, bonded by their mutual clumsiness. SGT. HOWELL (cont'd) You GRINNIN’ at me, boy?!
No Sir! But he still grins.
Howell double-time marches the men over to a rack of rifl  3.4.13 24.

Grab a gun and fall in! Everybody around him is grabbing a gun but Desmond just stares at the rack, some powerful emotion working on him. Irritated, Howell storms up behind Desmond. SGT. HOWELL (cont'd) Do we not have one in your size, soldier?!

(quietly) No, Sergeant. I can’t...won’t touch a gun. Everybody gets very quiet. Howell stares at Desmond in complete and utter disbelief. INT. CAPTAIN JACK GLOVER’S OFFICE - DAY Glover, a tough, no-nonsense former Detroit policeman, is Company B’s Commanding Officer, tasked with the almost impossible mission of creating an entirely new unit from scratch. His desk is piled high with reports, manuals, an documents and the office walls are patchwork of overdue w orders and tasks. At the moment, all of that is forgotten he tries to figure out the enigma that is Private Doss.
What exactly is the problem? Desmond responds respectfully, but we can sense he’s repeating himself.
The Army’s made a mistake. I told them when I signed up that...
(sharply) “Sir.” Desmond nods, flustered.
(to Glover) Yes Sir. Sorry, Sir.  3.4.13 25.
What you’re saying’s not possible, Private. Do you know why that is not possible?
No, Sir.
Because the United States Army does not make mistakes. Therefore, if there is a problem here, you must be that problem and I don’t want any damn problems in my Company.
Sir, I was supposed to be sent to a medical unit, not a rifle company, so I could--
--He’s a C.O. Howell hands Doss’s papers to Glover who glances at them suspicion.
You're a “Conscientious Objector?”
No, sir, I am a conscientious cooperator. I volunteered for active duty and signed on to be a medic.
Are you screwing with me, Doss?
No, sir. I don’t have a problem wearing a uniform or saluting the flag or doing my duty; only with the taking of human life. Glover can't believe what he’s hearing.
You don’t kill, is all. Any other requirements? Anything else we can do to ensure that you have a comfortable stay here in the Army?  3.4.13
I’m a Seventh Day Adventist so Saturdays are my Sabbath. And like I was trying to explain to the Sergeant here, I won’t touch a gun. Sir. Glover and Howell exchange looks.

Well, just so we’re clear, Doss, let me tell you my requirements. They're not as complicated as yours, in fact, they’re really very simple. As long as you’re part of this Company, you will obey my orders. Period. If you won’t do it here, I can’t trust you’1l do it in battle. I’m putting you in for a Section Eight, Psychiatric Discharge. Dismissed!
Sgt. Howell escorts Desmond back to the line, where the r of B Company are finishing calisthenics drills.
Think you're pretty smart, don’t you? Come in here, make a bunch of ridiculous demands, and think we’1l wash your ass outta the service, is that the plan?
There is no plan. I just want to serve my country. Howell studies Desmond skeptically, completely unconvince

Uh-huh. Well whatever your plan is, princess, but you’re not gonna get away with it. I guaran-damn- tee you that. Howell approaches the men with Desmond. Everyone comes to attention. SGT. HOWELL (cont'd) (addressing the men) Gentlemen! I want you to meet Private Desmond Doss. (MORE )

SGT. HOWELL (cont'd) Apparently, Private Doss does not believe in violence. He does not practice violence. He will not even touch a gun. Private Doss is a “Conscientious Objector.” Do not look to Private Doss to save your ass on the battlefield because he will undoubtedly be too busy with his conscience to help you! By this time, everyone is staring at Doss with undisguise suspicion, and open loathing. SGT. HOWELL (cont'd) I realize some of you may have strong feelings about this but the Government says we have to respect Doss’ rights. It’s what we men fight for: to protect our women and children and those less able. I will expect every man in this Company to give Private Doss the full measure of respect he’s due for the short time he will be with us. AM I CLEAR! ?

The men run the course, ducking under barbed wire, climbi wooden walls, splashing through water pits, etc. Desmond be skinny but he’s all muscle and has no trouble keeping with the front of the pack - a fact not lost on Smitty.

head_text.subj: COME ON YOU MAGGOTS, PICK IT UP

text: The men reach a sheer vertical wall with four knotted rop hanging from the top. Each soldier grabs a line and hauls himself up, hand over hand. Desmond finds himself right behind Smitty. As Smitty nears the top he glances behind at Desmond, climbing with surprising ease up the same rope just benea him. Smitty hesitates a fraction and then lets himself sl down the rope eighteen inches, his feet catching Desmond the face and chest and knocking him off the rope and onto ground. Smitty grins and easily pulls himself over the to  3.4.13 28. Desmond pulls himself up off the ground, a look of hardscrabble hillbilly determination on his face. He snat the rope, and quickly hoists himself up again.

Smitty cruises up ahead on the final portion of the cours victory assured. Desmond bears down and sprints full out until he catches up to a very surprised Smitty; Desmond g him a sideways glance, and pulls ahead to finish first in Company. Smitty is furious as Desmond leaves him in the dust.

A cavernous, drab, pinewood room with long tables seating fourteen men. Smitty sits at the head; Desmond is at the foot. Platters Pork Chops, peas, mashed potatoes and corn are passed dow By the time it reaches Desmond, there are only a handful peas and corn left. Uncomplainingly, Desmond fills his pl with what’s left. Waving one pork chop on his fork over the two other chops his plate, Smitty yells down the table at Desmond.
Hey, Doss! Sorry we ran out! Desmond smiles back politely.
That's alright, Smitty. I don’t eat meat.
What? Smitty pretends he can’t hear Doss. Yells out to Teach, sitting next to Doss at the end. SMITTY (cont'd) What’d the C.0O. say?
Says he don’t eat meat!
Don’t eat meat!  3.4.13 29.
Not a meat eater! From one man to the next, the word gets passed until it reaches Smitty. Smitty looks at Desmond, at a complete lo for words. Desmond smiles.
I like vegetables, though, plenty fine. Thanks. Smitty burns, feeling somehow that he’s been had.

In the precious half-hour to themselves before Lights Out the men play cards, read, chew the fat, or write letters. Desmond reaches into his shirt pocket and retrieves his N Testament. He runs his hands lightly over its cheap leath cover; he’s in sore need of comfort. A HAND reaches in and snatches the Bible away. Desmond ju up to see... Smitty standing there, grinning, holding his Bible.
What’cha got there, Dessie?
That’s my Bible.
Seems kinda small.
It's just the New Testament.
Half a Bible for half a man?
For Pete’s sake, Smitty, give him back his Bible.
Shut up, Teach. (back to Desmond) So how come you don’t fight? You think you're better than us?  3.4.13 30.
No.

What if you were attacked? Smitty suddenly BACKHANDS Desmond across the face, stagge him, and nearly knocking him down. Desmond touches his fa his lip is bleeding. The Barracks grows very quiet. Everybody stops what they' doing and watches. A few more men gather behind Smitty.
The Bible says to turn the other cheek.

Like this? Smitty SLAPS him again, this time in the other direction. More men gather. There is the smell of blood in the water SMITTY (cont'd) See, I don’t think this is a question of religion, fellas, I think this is just cowardice, plain and simple. Is that right, Doss? Are you chicken-shit, is that it? Desmond’s hands clench. It takes everything Desmond has n to leap at Smitty and tear his throat out.
Look out, Smitty! He’s getting hot!

Are you getting mad, Doss? Well, go on, take a poke! Tell you what, I'll give you a free shot. Go on. No? Smitty waves the Bible; Dorothy’s picture falls out. Desm reaches for it but Smitty is faster. SMITTY (cont'd) Hold on here! What's this?
That’s mine. Give it here!
Finder's keepers. (examining picture) (MORE )
SMITTY (cont'd) Hey now, this is a fine looking woman. Kind of woman who deserves a real man! The men whistle and catcall.
Give it back. Desmond has grown quiet...still...dangerous.
Please. Desmond’s eyes are hard as mountain granite.
Please.
“Please give it back, Smitty.”
Please give it back, Smitty. Smitty smiles slowly.

Nah, I‘1ll just keep it. Smitty tucks the picture into his pocket. Desmond's eyes dart up, full of fire-- And he sees Smitty smiling, waiting for him to strike bac and abandon everything that makes him who he is. Desmond lowers his arms. Smitty smirks, tosses Desmond’s Bible to Desmond and leav taking the crowd with him. Desmond, left alone, shunned as a coward, picks up his Bi and straightens the crooked pages out. A drop of blood fr his lip falls on the cover. Desmond wipes it off with his sleeve.
Do you hear voices, Desmond?  3.4.13 32.
COLONEL STELZER is a pinched face Psychiatrist with a receding hairline and a piercing gaze. Desmond sits in fr of him: nervous, angry, and defiant.
No, sir.
But I understand that God talks to you. Is that right?
Look, sir, I’m not some drooling backwoods idiot.
Is that how you think most people regard you? “A drooling idiot”?
I'm different. I know that. I don’t pretend to be something I’m not. I am what I am.
Sounds lonely. Desmond says nothing. COLONEL STELZER (cont’d) So you don’t hear voices.
I pray to God and I like to think He hears me but - it’s not a conversation, like we’re having.
So, God didn’t tell you not to touch a gun?
God says not to kill. That’s the Sixth Commandment.
I’m quite familiar with the scriptures, Private. And most people take that commandment to mean, “Don’t commit murder.” War, of course, is a completely different set of circumstances...  3.4.13 33.
I don’t see it that way...
..-King David was a “Warrior King,” and much loved by God.
And that’s the Old Testament! Jesus said, “A new commandment I give unto you, that you love one another and--"
Jesus didn’t say anything about not carrying a weapon! Did he?
No, sir.
Then why won’t you? Desmond hesitates - then sets his jaw.
Because I won’t. Sir.
Desmond returns to his cot and finds his pillow soaking w He can feel the men looking at him. Desmond wrings out th pillow as best he can.
Colonel Stelzer is now seated behind his desk. Captain Glover stands at attention.

It is my opinion that Private Doss is not insane or a malingerer. His religious views are certainly... unique, but they do not constitute grounds for a Section Eight Discharge. He is a legitimate Conscientious Objector and he must be allowed to work as a Combat Medic provided he qualifies in all other areas of his training. Glover is dumbfounded - and furious.  3.4.13 34.
And if I choose to appeal your decision, sir?
(with an edge) That would be unwise, Captain.
Glover strides furiously across the yard, Howell beside h
We're stuck with Doss...unless he requests a transfer. From now on he’s restricted to Barracks and KP. No leave.
Desmond is on his hands and knees, scrubbing the filthy toilets with a toothbrush.

Desmond stands in the crowded, smoky kitchen, washing an endless stack of dirty dishes. His hands are raw from the hot water and bleach. Through the window, he can see Smitty, Grease, Chief, and laughing and rough-housing with one another as they head of camp on a 24 hour pass. Smitty and Grease glance back at Doss, silhouetted in the mess hall window.
What a weirdo, huh? Complete fruitcake!
Shut up, Grease.

Somebody in the back yells, “Attention!” as Sgt. Howell enters in a surprise inspection. Everyone leaps to their feet. Howell prowls around silently, examining the barrac He stops in front of Doss’ bunk. Tugs on a corner.  3.4.13 35. Dissatisfied, Howell yanks the entire bedding off the cot throws it onto the floor.
Doss, your area is a disgrace! A pig stye! Smitty grins. Howell turns to him. SGT. HOWELL (cont'd) Something funny, Ryker?
No, sergeant.

What you men fail to recognize is that a unit is no better then its weakest member. To help you learn that lesson, there will be no passes for anyone this weekend and you will all be on KP! Right now, I want you in full gear for a twenty mile hike. LET’S GO! Howell exits. Everyone stares at Doss with utter contempt

Company B is in full combat uniforms carrying heavy backp and weapons - except Doss, who is unarmed and unburdened. heat is stifling and the men are sweating heavily as they slog through bogs and thick shrubs.
The men are in a state of collapse.
Take five! The Company falls to the ground where they are; some are tired to even move into the shade.
Something’s wrong with Teach. Doss moves to Teach - he’s hunched over, his face bone wh his skin dry and hot to the touch.
Headache is all.  3.4.13 36. Teach collapses.
The men wait, their mood sour. Nobody will look at Doss. Howell enters and the men rise to attention.

Private Epstein is recovering but he will not be returning to his unit; he’ll be discharged. We lost a good man today, through no fault of his own, because this Unit does not pull together; because this Unit is weak! Howell leaves. Slowly, every man in the unit looks at Dos

Desmond is showering, as he does all things now, alone. Smitty, Grease, and Chief enter. Just as Desmond turns to face them, Smitty punches Desmond in the face, knocking h to the floor. The other men close in around him and begin kicking and punching. Desmond curls up and tries to prote himself but he doesn’t fight back.

All the other members of the company sit on their bunks, looking at one another. The only SOUND is that of Desmond beating in the next room. Tex curls up in bed and slowly pulls his pillow over his ears to block out the noise.

The entire company stands at attention. The door opens an Sgt. Howell leads Desmond in. Desmond's face looks like chopped steak: bruised and swollen, his eyes bloodshot. H ribs obviously ache but he struggles to ignore his pain.

Last night, Private Doss was assaulted in these barracks. I want those men who took part to step forward. No one moves. Grease sneaks a nervous glance at Smitty.  3.4.13 SGT. HOWELL (cont'd) Reese? Something you’d like to share? Grease shakes his head.
No, sir.
Private Doss. Identify the men who beat you.
(quietly) No, sir.
You mean you don’t know who attacked you?
No, sir. Everybody is staring at Desmond. DESMOND (cont'd) I never said I was assaulted. Howell is stunned; he doesn’t know how to play this one.
What the hell are you saying, Doss?
I just - fell, is all. INT. GLOVER’S OFFICE - DAY
I can hardly leave you in the barracks; you might have another attack of falling sickness.
I'm willing to take that chance, sir.
The men don’t want you, Doss, they hate your guts! 37.  3.4.13 38.
Sir, they see me as responsible for their loss of leave, their extra duties, and what happened to Teach. They’re angry about that - as they were intended to be. Glover and Howell exchange looks.
If you’re accusing your Drill Instructor of... Desmond considers them coolly.
I’m not...sir. INT. FORT JACKSON OFFICER’S CLUB - EVENING Captain Glover shares a drink with his immediate superior COLONEL CUNNINGHAM.
He’s an embarrassment! We’1ll be the laughingstock of the Regiment.
He passed his Section 8; I’ve brought every pressure to bear that I can and he just won't quit.
You should court-martial him.
For what? Doss is a pain in the ass but he always toes the line.
Then find a way to move the line. Glover throws down his drink--and a thought hits him.

He told one of the guys he’s getting married this weekend, when he’s on furlough. Cunningham sees where this is going--and likes it.  3.4.13 39. INT. COLONEL CUNNINGHAM’S OFFICE - DAY - ONE WEEK LATER Cunningham sits at his desk, Sgt. Howell standing beside A line of men stretches through the office as each member Company B applies for, and gets, his long awaited “Two We Furlough.” Bored, Cunningham glances at each man’s papers and routinely stamps them. Until Desmond reaches the desk
Private Doss. I can’t authorize your pass.
Respectfully, sir, I’m long overdue. And I'm getting married this afternoon...
...-I’m not interested in your sob story. You’re not rifle qualified. Cunningham smiles, enjoying this.
I’m not required to carry a gun, sir. Colonel Stelzer...

Colonel Stelzer’s determination was... (reading from report) “Doss must be allowed to work as a Combat Medic provided he qualifies in all other areas of his training.” (closes file) You have not qualified on the rifle range, Private. Silence. Everybody in line - Smitty and the rest of Compa B - knows that Cunningham has put Desmond in a box. COLONEL CUNNINGHAM (cont’d) Show me you know how to handle a rifle and I’1l sign your furlough. Sergeant? Hand Private Doss your firearm. Sgt. Howell offers Doss his rifle.
Sir. I will not touch a gun, sir.  3.4.13 40.

I am not asking you, Private. That is a Direct Order. And there it is. Desmond doesn’t move. COLONEL CUNNINGHAM (cont’d) Pick up the rifle. (Doss remains still) I want you to think very carefully here, Doss. Pick up the gun; get your furlough and have a happy honeymoon. Refuse to pick up the gun and I will court martial you, and you will spend the next five years in the stockade. Desmond is tempted but...
No, sir.

Sergeant, you will note that Private Desmond Doss has disobeyed a direct order from his superior officer. Arrest him! Sgt. Howell leads Desmond out, past the other men of Comp B. Desmond neither seeks their pity nor their help. Smitty watches Desmond as he is led out. Disbelief. Anger Confusion. What the hell is it about this guy?
As the GUARD leads Desmond in, Desmond pleads--
I’ve got to make a phone call. Please.
No prisoner who’s been insubordinate gets phone calls. The Army lawyers will come to you.  3.4.13 4l.
A bare cell - a cot, a sink, a toilet. Desmond sits on th cot, reading the Bible Dorothy gave him. Desmond looks at his wrist watch: five minutes past six.
Dorothy stands at the altar in her wedding gown, her pare beside her. Next to them are Desmond’s parents. A tableau embarrassment and concern.
(quietly) How much longer would you like to wait, Dorothy? Dorothy speaks without a hint of doubt in her voice.
I think this is long enough. The Minister whispers to Dorothy.
I'm so very sorry...
I’m sure there’s a reason he’s not here. We’ll call you on Monday to reschedule.

Desmond paces in his cell, his knuckles clenched white wi barely contained fury. Suddenly, the dam bursts with a SC - a wrenching roar of frustration and pent-up anger. He grabs his cot and smashes it against the floor. He rips t sink off the wall. He smashes his hands against his steel door until his knuckles are bloody. Exhausted, he slumps down to the floor.
Desmond’s lawyer, CAPTAIN DANIELS, is a nervous young man with a mustache so meagre it seems painted on.

Private, outbursts like last night don’t help.  3.4.13 42. Desmond shrugs, sunk in misery. CAPTAIN DANIELS (cont’d) There is some good news. They’ve indicated if you plead guilty, the Army will give you a dishonorable discharge, and you can go home. How’s that sound?
If that’s the good news, I sure don’t want to hear the bad.

Look, Doss, Military Justice is a whole different animal. We’re at war! The needs of a Conscientious Objector are hardly a priority. Take the deal and be grateful. INT. DESMOND’S CELL - DAY Desmond sits on his cot, reading Dorothy’s Bible. The doo opens and to Desmond’s surprise, Captain Glover enters. Desmond stands and salutes. Glover ignores his salute.
Sit down. Desmond sits, uncertain. Glover looks out the window at t parade ground, at the men training outside. He sees Desmond's Bible; picks it up. CAPTAIN GLOVER (cont’d) This your Bible?
New Testament. My fiance gave it to me when I joined up. Glover shakes his head and puts the Bible back down on th bunk.
You probably think I’m a real son of a bitch who cares more about regulations then he does about his men.

Did I give you permission to speak? (beat) The U.S. Army didn’t always arm its medics. Did you know that? The Geneva Convention expressly allows Medics to be armed and to use their weapons in defense but some nice fellow at the Pentagon decided, like you, that he knew better. But after we invaded Attu last year, a thousand Japs armed with rifles and home-made spears launched a banzai attack in the middle of the night directly on the hospital tents where the medics and their wounded lay sleeping. Our boys fought back as best they could with whatever they could find but hundreds died. Captain Glover looks at Doss. CAPTAIN GLOVER (cont’d) I don’t give a rat’s ass about your principals because the Japs don’t. One of them comes at you and some wounded soldier what are you gonna fight him with, Doss? Your New Testament?
With everything I have, sir. I'm prepared to give my life for my men.

You don’t win wars, Doss, by giving up your life! You win wars by taking them. (beat) Plead guilty and I will see that you receive an Honorable Discharge. There’s no shame in that. Go home and pray, and let the soldiers go over there and fight.
I can’t do that, sir. The two men stare at one another.
Guard! 43.

A GUARD unlocks the door. CAPTAIN GLOVER (cont’d) Your hearing is tomorrow morning. If I can’t change your mind, maybe she can. Glover leaves. Desmond rises, afraid to hope, but it’s tr Dorothy enters the cell. Desmond and Dorothy eye each oth unsure of how the other will react. Dorothy moves into hi arms.
I...you know I would’ve been there if there'd been any way...
What’d they do to you? Dorothy sits on the cot; Desmond sits close beside her, taking his swollen hands in hers.
I went a couple of rounds with the wall and lost. Pretty much the story of me and the army.
They say you could go to prison, Desmond. Leavenworth. For a long, long time. Desmond is nervous but tries not to show it.
I don’t think that’1l happen.
But you don’t know it, do you?
I've come too far. I won’t quit.
You tried, Desmond; nobody can say you didn’t. Just say whatever they want you to say and come home! There’s plenty of things you can do for the war effort at home.
I believe in my heart that being a medic is what I’m supposed to do!  3.4.13 45. Desmond realizes he’s raised his voice more than he meant Dorothy is starting to seethe.
This is just pride, Desmond! Pride and stubbornness! Don’t confuse your will with the Lord’s!

(reserved) I could say the same thing to you. Silence. Both are miserable. DESMOND (cont'd) I want to do right in God’s eyes and - yeah, I may be - like you say - prideful. If I am, it’s because I want so badly to be the kind of man you could be proud of. And I’m scared of failing. Dorothy looks at him - a mixture of love and pity. And th she puts her arms around him and holds him close.
Desmond sits on the floor of his cell, alone, lost in thought. He makes a decision, one that leaves him feeling defeated. He rises and bangs on the door.
Guard! I want to see my lawyer.
Sgt. Howell leads Desmond to the courtroom.

You're quitting just in time, Doss. Regiment's finally shipping out; we're going to get us a real piece of this war. (confiding) You know, some of us had a pool going on you. Hollywood was giving 20 to one odds.
Where’d you put your money?  3.4.13 46.

Let’s just say, you had me a little worried there for awhile. They pass soldiers practicing BAYONET DRILL, lunging at a clubbing padded wooden stanchions with their rifles while their Drill Instructor urges them on. Desmond stops to wa
Kill!
Kill!
I CAN’T HEAR YOU!
Kill!

head_text.subj: IS THAT THE BEST YOU CAN DO

text: Desmond regards all these young men, so confident of thei power, acting invulnerable--as if none of them will be wounded, or killed. Sgt. Howell tugs at Desmond's sleeve pulling him back to reality. He follows but there’s a different look in his e now.

Tom Doss drives his car up to the house like a madman, leaving deep ruts in the muddy front yard. He leaps out o the car leaving the door open behind him and the engine s running. He hurries up the steps to the front porch where Dot and Bess have been anxiously waiting for him.
Did you get it?! Tom hands her an envelope.
Right there. Go on! Dorothy starts down the steps. Stops and looks back  3.4.13 47.
You're coming aren’t you? A flash of pain crosses Tom’s eyes.
No. You go. I...Tell him this was your doing.
But it wasn’t.
In a way it was. Go on...you’re gonna be late if you don’t get started. Dorothy starts to turn away, but then stops again. There a gentle strength in her face, the kind particular to Southern women.
Mr. Doss... When Desmond and I Marry, you’ll be my father too. And I'm telling you: he’d want to know this...from you. A flash of pain shoots across Tom's face.
I’m no good at this stuff. You go. With one last look and the hint of a nod, Dorothy turns b toward the car and heads off.

A conference room has been hastily transformed into a courtroom. The JUDGE, a JAG Officer, sits at the far end behind a table on a raised dais. Desmond sits at a table with his lawyer, Captain Daniels. The Prosecutor sits at nearby table next to Colonel Cunningham and Captain Glove Cunningham looks very pleased. Glover, on the other hand, oddly subdued. MP’s flank the doors. There are a handful chairs in the back - empty. Desmond looks around in vain Dorothy, but she is not there. Nobody is there for him.
This is a hearing into the matter of Private Desmond Doss. The charge is Disobeying a Direct Order from his Commanding Officer. How says the Defendant?  3.4.13 Captain Daniels rises.
May it please the court, Private Doss is prepared to enter a Guilty plea.
Is that so, Private? A moment. Desmond rises slowly.
No, sir. I’ve changed my mind. There is an unpleasant stir in the courtroom.
You wish to proceed with a Court Martial? Desmond’s lawyer, Captain Daniels, whispers to him--
Doss, what the hell are you--
(ignoring Daniels; to the Judge) If you say so.
This is not a game, Private. Your lawyer has acquainted you with all of the possible consequences?
Yes, sir.
Very well. Do you deny disobeying Colonel Cunningham’s order?
No, sir.
It would seem you leave the court with very limited options. (a moment) Why is it so important to you, given your refusal to even touch a gun, to serve in a combat unit? 48.
Desmond takes a breath and wipes his sweaty hands on his pants. He’s working this out on his feet; trying to give form to his feelings.

When the Japs attacked Pearl Harbor, I took it personally. Everyone I knew was on fire to join up. Two men in my home town who were declared 4-F killed themselves because they couldn’t serve. I had a job in a defense plant and could've taken a deferment but it didn’t seem right. It didn’t seem right to me that other folks should fight and die for my rights, including my right to believe what I believe. Being a medic seems perfect. I'’11 be right in the middle with the other guys, no less danger, but instead of taking life, I’1l be saving it. With the world so set on tearing itself apart, it doesn’t seem such a bad thing to me to want to put a little bit of it back together. The men in the court can’t embrace Desmond’s position, bu they can’t deny his sincerity. DESMOND (cont'd) All I’ve ever wanted was a chance to serve my country and to protect my fellow soldiers. The Judge frowns.

While the sentiments expressed are laudable, the facts of the case seem incontestable. I have no choice but to recommend we go forward... The door opens and Dorothy enters. She spots Desmond and rushes past the startled guards to him and his lawyer. Sh hands the envelope to Captain Daniels. JUDGE (cont'd) How did this woman get in here? Guards!  3.4.13 50. The MPs close in. Daniels rises, Dorothy's open envelope his hand.
Your Honor! I have a letter here! From Washington! The Judge beckons and Daniels hands him the letter. The Judge reads it. He glances up at Desmond.

(reading aloud) “The defendant’s rights as a Conscientious Objector are protected by an Act of Congress and he cannot be compelled to waive those rights. That includes his refusal to bear arms of any kind.” Signed by the War Services Commander, Washington, D.C. A stake through the heart of the charges against Desmopnd The Judge looks over at Cunningham and Glover. JUDGE (cont'd) We could proceed, of course, should the Colonel insist...? Colonel Cunningham rises stiffly.
I withdraw the charges, sir.
Then this case is dismissed. Private Doss, you may resume your duties and begin training as a combat medic. As the courtroom clears, Desmond hugs Dorothy.
How did you do this?! Over her shoulder, Desmond catches a glance from Glover - there is no look of forgiveness on his face, nor any sign forgetting this defeat.

Desmond lies in bed, absently toying with the WEDDING RIN that now graces his left hand.  3.4.13 51. Dorothy turns off the light in the bathroom and climbs in bed, wearing a nightgown and her own ring. They hold each other a moment and savor the look in each other’s eyes.
Now, I haven't changed my mind about what you’re doing and I don’t want you to go. But I love you and if you really think this is what you’re meant to do, then that’s the way it is. Only...
What?
You don’t come home to me and I’11 make you sorry you were ever born. Dorothy tries to smile but her tears betray her and then Desmond’s mouth is kissing her and they are lost in each other.

Titles: OKINAWA. APRIL, 1945 The Liberty Division has finally made it into combat, but their war shows little excitement and even less glory. A cold, heavy rain dampens spirits and turns the primitive into a morass of mud. Company B slogs through the mire as they try to get up to the front line. Desmond walks in the rear - alone - the Red Cross insigni his arm and his helmet evidence that he is now, finally, Medic. He carries a full field backpack plus three plasma sets, a surgical kit, and two canteens, one full of water one full of rubbing alcohol. Desmond’s training hasn’t brought him any closer to the m who still noticeably shun him. And he remains the only ma among them, indeed the only man in the entire US army, wh unarmed. Bruno shifts the heavy Flamethrower equipment on his back BRUNO “B” MAZILLI Thought the Pacific was supposed to be warm.  3.4.13 52.
That's what that zippo on your back is for. On either side of the road, the soil is deep red. Rice paddies and cornfields alternate between low pine-covered limestone and ancient coral ridges.
Doesn’t look a whole lot different than South Carolina. Chief points at an elaborate womb-shaped rock structure o one hill.
Won't see that in South Carolina - that’s an Okinawan tomb.
How come they don’t bury their dead like decent people? Chief shrugs. A sudden DISTANT RUMBLE of artillery pierce the air and every man perks up.
(nervously) Ours or theirs? The men up ahead in the line are stepping over to the sid the road. Horns of approaching trucks are heard honking loudly.

Give’em room! Make way! Company B huddles miserably off the road as a convoy of A TRUCKS rumbles past them in the opposite direction. The first trucks are loaded with AMERICAN SOLDIERS, gaunt and haunted-looking. Their clothes are tattered and filth but much worse is the vacant look of misery in their eyes
Who’s that?
The 96th; what’s left of them. The guys we're replacing. The trucks keep coming by, one after another, full of sil men with ghostly pallor and dazed faces.  3.4.13 53.
How long were they on the line?
Two weeks.

Jesus. And then the last five trucks pass by - full of DEAD SOLDIERS, each man draped in his own damp poncho and then stacked like wood, four feet high. The men get very quiet. Desmond takes off his helmet and others follow suit. The rain beats down on their bare hea and runs off their ponchos. The last truck rumbles past. There is only the SOUND of the wind and the rain. Captain Glover steps back into the road.
(very subdued) Let's go.

Company B enters a typical Okinawan farmstead: low stone surrounding a central building with a heavy tile roof and upswept eaves. It appears abandoned, pock marked by morta rounds and machine gun fire, but nobody is taking any chances. The men move cautiously, guns ready. SERGEANT JONES hurri up alongside Glover.

Sir, we got three Nips coming in, want to surrender. One of ‘em looks like he might be an officer. Glover, Doss, Smitty and several others follow Sgt. Jones the rear entrance of the compound to the edge of...
A group of soldiers stand watching in amusement as three JAPANESE SOLDIERS approach - one riding a bicycle, one sitting on the handlebars, and the third running alongsid holding a large WHITE FLAG.

Hold your fire!  3.4.13 54. Several of the US soldiers look back to Glover in confusi A few wave their arms at the Japanese to halt. As the Japanese get within fifteen yards they abruptly stop and abandon the bicycle. All of them pull out GRENADES and th them at the Americans! The grenades explode and simultaneously the Americans open up. In the brief fire- fight, five American soldiers are wounded and all three Japanese go down. CAPTAIN GLOVER (cont’d) Cease Fire! Medic! It was all so fast; Desmond can hardly believe it. CAPTAIN GLOVER (0.C.) (cont'd)

Desmond grabs his kit and hurries towards the closest wou American. It’s not until he’s almost on him that he can see it’s actually two men - Bruno, with a gaping stomach wound, an lying beside him, Kirzinski, dead, his sightless eyes sta up at the sky. His first combat casualties. The classroom can’t prepare you for this: the smell of burning flesh; the sight of arterial blood seeping into t ground; the pitiful SOUND of men whimpering with pain. Desmond takes a hurried breath and checks the Bruno’s pul
BRUNO “B” MAZILLI Is that you, Doss?

Don’t speak. Save your breath. Desmond starts to cut away Bruno’s clothes to get at his wound. Bruno is badly rattled, shaking with pain and terr the look on Desmond’s face isn’t comforting. BRUNO “B” MAZILLI (whispering) It wasn’t - like - they said it - would be. Desmond stops, confused, for only a moment as Bruno’s eye roll back in his head.

He’s going into shock!  3.4.13 55. Desmond quickly injects Bruno with morphine and then wrap tourniquet around his upper arm. He pulls out a plasma un a box with two bottles and a two way needle - and connect the bottles with the needle. While the liquid is filling dried plasma, Desmond pulls out a sterile IV kit and sets up. He inserts one end into the now liquid plasma and the other into Bruno’s arm. Desmond releases the tourniquet a the plasma begins to flow into the patient. Desmond waits an anxious moment and then, as the color returns to Bruno’s face, he breathes a sigh of relief. DESMOND (cont'd)
A Two Man stretcher team runs up. Desmond watches them lo his patient and carry him away. Only then does Desmond realize how much his hands are shaking.

As the last of the American wounded are evacuated, Desmon moves to the Japanese bodies. To his surprise, one of the is still alive. It is Desmond's first glimpse of the enemy and despite th treachery of their assault, this soldier does not appear formidable. The Japanese Soldier looks young, barely out his teens, and so malnourished he’s more skin and bones t anything else. Blood bubbles at the corners of his mouth. He looks at Desmond with absolute terror in his eyes. Desmond doesn’t hesitate, he squats down beside the wound soldier and starts to treat his wounds.
Leave him be. Desmond looks up in surprise at Smitty standing over him, service revolver drawn, glowering at the wounded Japanese soldier. Glover strides over.
Sons of bitches came in under a white flag. (to everyone) No more prisoners! Ever. You get a clean shot on one of them, you take it! (to Desmond) Leave him alone.  3.4.13 56.
(quietly) It’s my job, sir; take care of the wounded.
Not these wounded. BOOM! Smitty shoots the wounded Japanese soldier at such close range that flecks of blood spatter Desmond. Glover has already begun to walk off. Smitty looks at Desmond.
He’s all yours now.
Nervous sentries guard the farmhouse perimeter in two man foxholes. It’s pitch black out and the night is foggy, ev further obscuring vision.

Those men not on duty - including Smitty - sit together a eat dinner or smoke. Desmond sits by himself, ignored by the rest of the compa eating cold K rations. The door opens and another soldier, Schecter, enters. Schecter is clearly a veteran; he looks ragged and beat b he has a warm, engaging manner. He carries the equipment a medic but wears none of the identifying insignia. Irv glances around until he spots Desmond and then comes over him, hand extended.
You Doss? Irv Schecter out of the 96th. You and me are the only medics they got now in this area so it looks like we’re gonna be working together.

The 96th? You just come off the line? Schecter barely nods, ignoring Smitty, and hands Desmond medical supply package which Desmond starts to open.  3.4.13 57. SMITTY (cont'd) What’s it like up there? Schecter finally turns to face Smitty. He considers hima minute, something flinty in his gaze that makes even Smit uncomfortable.

“Hacksaw Ridge.” That’s where it’s all happening right now. They threw us off it six times and after the last time there wasn’t anything left of the 96th. Smitty and the rest of the men are silent. Desmond now ha the package open to reveal bandages and surgical dressing which are all brown instead of white.
Are these bandages OK? Irv turns back to Desmond.

They're sterile, if that’s what you mean. We started out using regular white bandages but they show up too easy and the Japs deliberately target the wounded. And take off all your Red Cross markings and put some tape over your helmet. Japs put a premium on shooting medics. They’11l let a whole squad go by just to get a clean shot at one of us.
How come?

‘Cause they’re animals. I’ve seen them fake being wounded, calling out “Medic!” just to lure you in. Then... Schecter makes a slashing motion across his throat. SCHECTER (cont'd) There isn’t any Geneva convention out there. There aren’t any rules at all. The men all look at one another. Schecter hands Desmond a roll of black tape.  3.4.13 58.

It's a very different Company on the march today. Several men have been killed or wounded and the true nature of th abyss which yawns before them has been glimpsed. Desmond glances up at the terrain around them. They are crossing an open valley, half a mile wide. A ser of gradual slopes lead to their ultimate objective up ahe a long, high rocky escarpment:

The jagged Ridge runs west, to their right, all the way t the sea. The top of the ridge is protected by a SHEER CLI which is 70 feet high. At the eastern end of the ridge, to the Company’s left, i series of sharp ROCK PINNACLES, 480-500 feet tall, which dominate the entire formation. With the sun behind it, throwing its enormous shadow out towards the men, the entire structure feels oppressive an malevolent. The Company has stopped - every man in it absorbing their first glance of the obstacle ahead.

Let's go! The Company reluctantly begins to move forward. They come upon the first of several unburied JAPANESE COR -bloated, decomposing bodies drawing clouds of flies. The faces are stretched tight, jaws open, as if the dead are still screaming. A cloud-like dread begins to descend on the men. Desmond notices the FOOTPRINTS of Rennelli in front of hi The stream trickling down the middle of the road is chang color, getting redder. Blood red. And then it dawns on Desmond that the ground is so SATURA WITH BLOOD that they are literally walking through a stre of it. As every man comes to the same shocking realization.
Is that...? It’s not a stream, it’s blood!  3.4.13 59.
(crossing himself) Lord have mercy.

Titles: April 24, 1945. First Assault. The First Battalion’s lines are 50 yards from the norther edge of the Ridge, running from the Pinnacle rocks on the left, to about 500 yards to the right. Up close, the Ridge is an even more rugged barrier, actua an ancient coral reef. Rain and wind erosion have carved innumerable gullies, caves, and holes in the cliff face. weeks of combat have left their mark as well. Whatever tr or shrubbery once existed here, all that remains now are blasted, charred stumps and blackened craters. The men of the Company B have found shelter wherever they - some in natural defensive positions among the rocks, ot in foxholes they have scraped out themselves, or that wer left by the 96th.

Captain Glover has set up his Command Post with the plato critical communication gear in a hole between two huge ro on the lower side of the hill. In front, charred logs hav been piled up and covered with dirt for extra protection. Twenty yards behind the CP and dug in behind another pile rocks is the MEDICAL RECEIVING STATION, the first stop in chain of medical care for evacuated casualties.
Captain Glover has the NCOs, Squad Leaders, and Medics gathered around while he goes over the plan of battle.

The enemy will be softened up by a mortar and artillery barrage. At 1700 hours, when those shadows give us some cover on the face, Companies B and A will assault the ridge. A will take the pinnacles on our left, while we seize the section of the ridge directly in front of us. (MORE )

CAPTAIN GLOVER (cont'd) The two companies will then link up on top and establish a new defensive perimeter which we will hold at all costs. Glover hesitates. CAPTAIN GLOVER (cont’d) We need Okinawa as a staging area for the invasion of Japan but the entire movement of the Army has been held up, right here. Our Navy is stuck off the coast getting hit by Kamikaze attacks and losing a ship and a half a day. Hacksaw Ridge is the key to their defences. We take Hacksaw, we get Okinawa. We get Okinawa, we take Japan. So the sooner we get this done, the sooner we can all go home. Questions? The men are silent. CAPTAIN GLOVER (cont’d) OK. See you on top. Everyone start to leave. CAPTAIN GLOVER (cont’d) Doss. Desmond returns. Glover waits until they are alone. CAPTAIN GLOVER (cont’d) That damn ridge has cost us so many Americans we don’t even have an accurate count yet. When we attack, the only hope any man has of surviving is to kill every Jap he sees without hesitation. Whatever nonsense you believe, you keep it to yourself--and do your job. You understand me?
Yes, sir.

The men wait nervously in their positions, checking their weapons and ammunitions. Some men have short six foot LADDERS and heavy CLIMBING ROPES with GRAPPLING HOOKS.  3.4.13 61. Over their heads, U.S. mortars and artillery shells arc i and explode on top of the Ridge. As medics, Desmond and Schecter wait the standard 10-15 f behind the men. They will follow the attack from this position so they can better see when someone goes down. Schecter goes over his supplies obsessively. Desmond closes his eyes and says a silent prayer. Several the other men notice. Desmond whispers “Amen” and takes h New Testament from his pocket, running his fingers over i cover. Suddenly, the artillery barrage stops. Desmond opens his eyes and nervously tucks his Bible away in his breast poc Captain Glover looks at his watch. It’s time. He hand signals the “go ahead” to his squad leaders.

With the SCOUTS, including Chief, leading the way, the me move as fast and as silently as they can, scrambling over rubble at the base of the Ridge, hand over hand. This is the Charge of the Light Brigade. Every man is utterly terrified and is forcing himself to move forward by a she act of will. TWO TEAMS set up ladders against the cliff face. Immediately, two men with ropes climb to the top of the ladders and toss their grappling hooks onto the lip of th Ridge, trying to grab a secure hold. Surprisingly there is little enemy resistance--only some sniping and a few knee mortar rounds. One soldier goes do Desmond hurries towards the wounded soldier when a mortar round lands nearby on the rocks. A handful of razor-sharp shards of limestone smack Desmond in the right side, spin him around, and knocking him down to the ground! Desmond’s hand and face are bleeding. He looks in wonder his own blood - half terrified at how close the shell was half delighted at the modest nature of his injury. Desmond wipes the blood off on his own shirt, and plunges back towards the line. The soldiers swarm up the cliff face and finally onto the of the Ridge which is revealed to be a small plateau.  3.4.13 62.
Desmond hauls himself up the last few feet of rope and onto...

The edge here is maybe fifteen feet wide and two to six f deep. Dotted with boulders and stumps of shattered trees, rises up towards the plateau in a small BERM. This tiny protected area is all the shelter the plateau offers. Captain Glover and the rest of the men are huddled behind berm, peering cautiously over the edge. Desmond reaches them just as Glover gives the signal to m forward across the berm and onto...

The plateau, seemingly open, is actually crisscrossed by numerous cunningly hidden small RAVINES and GULLIES, and still smoking from the pre-assault bombardment. There are Japanese forces or defensive structures visible. That doesn’t mean they aren’t there. As Glover and his men mov out into the open, all hell breaks loose. HEAVY MACHINE GUN FIRE from three cleverly camouflaged positions rakes the top of the plateau. Simultaneously, there is a shower of HAND GRENADES from individual Japanese Soldiers hidden in natural folds and made trenches in the ground, or popping out of camouflage “Spider Holes.” Japanese KNEE MORTARS, 81 MM MORTARS, and even 47 MM guns launched from positions hidden in the rear of the Ridge - “Reverse Slope” - fall among the Americans with devastati results. The Company responds with their own grenades, carbines, a BAR but the enemy is so well hidden it’s hard to find a target. Immediately, the Company starts taking casualties In front of Desmond, a SOLDIER takes the full blast from Japanese mortar shell and is tossed up into the air and backwards, slamming into the ground. Desmond launches himself over the berm and runs to the do man, ignoring the firing and explosions all around him. T man has lost both his legs from the knees down.  3.4.13 63. Schecter runs past Desmond and glances down at the wounde soldier. He shakes his head.
Waste of time! Come on! The wounded soldier grabs Desmond's arm.
Don’t leave me! Please, God, don’t leave me! Desmond leans close to the soldier - he can’t be more tha nineteen.
I’m not going anywhere! What’s your name? Desmond quickly injects the soldier with morphine and tie tourniquet around the stumps of his legs.
S.s..s..Stevens. Private J. Stevens.
Where you from, Private Stevens?
Buffalo.

That's near Niagara Falls, right? Always wanted to see that. OK, I’ve got to get you off of here. Arms around my neck; hold on now! Desmond picks up the Wounded Soldier and carries him to t cliff edge. Desmond looks down. It’s seventy feet straight down. It didn’t seem so far climbing up but it looks like the bottom of the Grand Can from here. Desmond wraps a bandage around his right hand and grabs o of the climbing ropes, while he simultaneously tries to secure the soldier with his left hand. Suddenly, there is an ear-splitting ROAR, like a freight train approaching, moving down towards him. Desmond looks to see...  3.4.13 64. A huge JAPANESE SPIGOT MORTAR SHELL, the size of a garbag can, stuffed with twenty pounds of high explosives, arcin down directly towards him. Desmond looks around in terror. To jump from the cliff wo kill both him and his patient. Desmond pushes the Wounded Soldier down and covers him with his own body... The shell passes within six inches of Desmond and lands a the base of the cliff - and fails to go off! Desmond shudders with relief. Shakily, Desmond secures the wounded Soldier, grabs the r with his one free hand, and using his feet to slow his descent, jumps off the cliff and slides down the rope. Desmond can’t control their motion very well and the rope begins to swing, throwing them into the cliff face. Desmo tries to put himself between the rock and the wounded Soldier.

Bruised and battered, Desmond reaches the bottom; terra f never felt so good. The Spigot Mortar Shell that missed t is sticking out of the mud - somehow it had landed on its back and thus failed to explode. Desmond has to steady himself at the thought of how close he came to dying but has a job to do: DESMOND (cont'd)

A FOUR MAN STRETCHER team races out from their position hidden in the rocks and grabs the wounded soldier. Desmond runs alongside as the Stretcher Bearers carry the soldier back through their own lines towards the...
.+-where a DOCTOR is already treating incoming casualties He glances at the wounded Soldier with a critical eye.

Plasma! Desmond watches while the Doctor goes to work. He glances at Desmond, gesturing furiously at the soldier’s mangled legs.  3.4.13 65. DOCTOR (cont'd) You ever hear of triage? He won't last a day! And if he does, he won’t thank you! (to an assistant)

head_text.subj: GET ME SOME PLASMA OVER HERE

text: Desmond stumbles out of the aid station and back towards Escarpment. He stops in shock as he sees the rest of Comp B scrambling down off Hacksaw Ridge in a frantic, helples retreat. It is utter chaos.

As Japanese mortars sporadically lay down harassment fire Desmond crouches in his foxhole looking through his K Rat packages for his dinner options: “Ham and Egg”, “Beef”, “ and Cheese.” All meat. Resigned to going hungry, he pulls the single hardtack cracker out of his kit and munches on slowly, washing it down with water from his canteen. Smitty comes sprinting over and jumps into Desmond’s foxh Desmond is surprised, but pleased at his company. For his part, Smitty is trying to put on a good face but clearly, he’s unnerved by their first combat experience.
Hey.

Not here to be sociable. Captain wants all the medics to have a rifleman with them at night, in case one of those Jap infiltration teams gets through. I drew the short straw. As Smitty talks, he nervously lays out his weapons: he ja his K-bar knife into the ground for quick access alongsid his pistol, his carbine, an extra magazine, and two grena SMITTY (cont'd) I couldn't see them up there! It was like they were invisible or something. You knew they were there because they were tearing us up, but you couldn’t see them.
Camouflage, I guess.

Like ghosts. You gonna eat that?  3.4.13 66. Desmond shakes his head and Smitty snatches the Beef pack rips it open, and stuffs it in his mouth. SMITTY (cont'd) Mortars are the worst. I hate the way they sound coming in on you but Jones told me that it’s the one you don’t hear that kills you. I think Grease wet himself. He wasn’t the only one. (slight hesitation) Noticed you were talking to yourself plenty, going up.
Praying.
Never been too big on church and stuff like that.
Don’t need church to pray. Don’t need anything. It’s just...you talking to God.
Uh-huh. He ever talk back?
Not like this. More just a feeling of being heard. Safe.

Safe? Smitty looks around at the desolate landscape. SMITTY (cont'd) That'd be a good trick. Smitty clearly seems to be struggling with something. Aft a moment of hesitation he reaches into his pocket and han something to Desmond. SMITTY (cont'd) Here. Desmond looks down to find the photo of Dorothy that Smit had stolen from him earlier in his hands. It’s torn in so places and dirty in others, but the sight of Dorothy brin an almost forgotten comfort to Desmond in that dark place  3.4.13 67. SMITTY (cont'd) I never felt good about taking it. And never could throw it away.
smitty...
Don’t think this means we’re square or nothing. You’re still weird to me. But... you did good today.
Glover addresses the Squad Leaders and Medics.

OK, I know we got our asses handed to us but at least we’ve got a better sense of what’s on top. The Japs have built a three Bunker system in a triangle formation towards the southeast corner. We neutralize those bunkers and we should be able to roll over the ridge.
We're too slow putting men and supplies up there the way we did it yesterday. Not to mention getting our casualties down.

Yeah. I asked the Navy for some heavy cargo nets. I figure we can attach them to those tree stumps up on the lip and move our men up a heck of a lot faster. Gonna need volunteers to tie those nets up. There is silence. The men avoid looking at one another. Finally, Desmond raises his hand.
I’1l go. A moment, as the men take this in. Then Smitty raises his hand, followed by Sgt. Jones.  3.4.13 68.

Desmond, Smitty, and Jones wait in the relative security the foot of the cliff. Each man ties a rope to his waist, the end of which is secured to one end of two cargo nets lashed together. Finished, the men pick up their climbing ropes with the grappling hooks. They’re ready. Glover notices a COMBAT PRESS team approaching.
(incredulously) What do you want?
For the folks back home. Glover shakes his head and nods at his three rope men.

Smile pretty for the camera, fellas. Desmond, Smitty and Jones force themselves to smile for t photographer. Glover signals and his men prop three makeshift ladders u against the cliff face. Desmond and the two others begin climb as fast as they can while the ropes attached to the are carefully played out. The other soldiers in the unit watch in surprise and even admiration as Desmond scoots up the ladder, all the while mumbling a prayer. He leaves Smitty and Jones struggling slowly behind. Near the top, Desmond throws his grappling hook up and secures a hold, then hoists himself, hand by hand, up ove the...

Being sure to keep his head down beneath the height of th berm, Desmond quickly removes the rope from his waist and loops it around a thick tree stump. Lying back on the ground, feet braced against the stump, Desmond pulls with all his might to hoist the cargo net u the cliff face. By this time, both Smitty and Jones are o either side of him, pulling up their loads. From below, Desmond can hear Glover call:  3.4.13 69.

Tie it off! Desmond wraps the line around the tree trunk one last tur for extra measure and then secures it with a knot. He mov to the edge of the cliff and looks down. He is fearless. Below him the Photographer is clicking away. Smitty joins Desmond, grinning and posing for the camera.
Like frickin’ Iwo Jima!
Alright, ladies, get down offa there before you get your movie star asses shot to pieces.

Glover lays out the refined attack plan for the squad leaders, medics, and the Combat Press Team. On the ground front of him, Glover has constructed a crude diagram of t plateau using twigs and stones.

Company A will start the assault on the pinnacles to draw their focus and then we head up under covering mortar fire to keep the Japs pinned down. Soon as we’re in position, we pour in small arms fire while the Demo Squad gets close enough to toss in a satchel charge on the main bunker.
